awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Quantifying Holocene Climate Variations through Data Assimilation using Proxies and General Circulation Models (GCMs) Output
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop a proxy-model assimilation framework for the Holocene period by combining proxy data and model simulations. The developed framework will allow to address critical questions about the temperature trends during the Holocene which show a discrepancy between observations and models. In addition, the climate dynamics underlying major hydrological changes-Drying- in western North America and Northern Africa will be investigated. To improve the model-data comparison, the researchers will use a proxy-system modeling approach in order to improve the interpretation of the climate signal recorded in the Holocene proxy-records, including seasonality of temperature and precipitation.

The potential Broader Impacts include a greater understanding of the Holocene climate dynamics, investigating the mismatch between model simulations and observation of temperature trends during the Holocene; and major hydroclimate shifts in northwestern US and North Africa. A Holocene multi-variable reconstruction at annual resolution and a curated Holocene proxy-record database will be developed and made available for the broader climate community. Two workshops on paleoclimate data assimilation will be organized for graduate students and early career scientists to train the next generation of paleoclimate scientists. The project will support three early career scientists and a graduate student.
 
The Holocene multi-variables reconstruction and proxy-network will be useful products that will benefit the paleoclimate community at large.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Fundamental aspects of Holocene climate evolution and dynamics remain uncertain or unknown. Yet this is the most recent geologic epoch and the epoch that has the most potential to tell us about current climate. The primary goals of this project were to develop a new global reconstruction of climate throughout the Holocene and to analyze its major climatic features from a global perspective. The new Holocene reconstruction was created using paleoclimate data assimilation, an approach that statistically combines proxy observations with the physical relationships from climate models. Using this new reconstruction we addressed the following important scientific topics: (1) We worked towards resolving the "Holocene Temperature Conundrum", in which proxies and models show different signs of temperature change since the mid-Holocene. (2) We explored the impact of different forcings on climate throughout the Holocene. (3) We quantified and investigated regional hydroclimate changes over the Holocene. In addition, we made our new global reconstruction freely available to the broader scientific community and held two multi-day online workshops on the topic of paleoclimate data assimilation. These workshops featured live and recorded lectures and interactive, guided programming activities. We accepted a total of about 200 applicants from 27 different countries for attendance at the workshops.
